  physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a Chairil Anwar
 one of Southeast Asia\u0027s most important poets. The figure\u0027s head angles away from the audience
 and he is depicted to be wearing a blue shirt and is himself set against a colourful background. Yellow has been used to indicate the colour of the figure\u0027s skin. The artist\u0027s signature and date of work is found on the bottom left corner

  subject_terms_1: figurative art  forms of expression (artistic concept)  identity

  subject_terms_2: Figurative painting Figurative art Figurative expressionism  Identity  Anwar
 Chairil
 1922-1949

  subject_terms_3: visual arts

  sgcool_label_text: Executed after the Japanese Occupation
 the work is a portrait of one of the most important poets in Southeast Asia. Here we can still observe Apin’s impressionist tendencies
 similar to the works done during his  PERSAGI days. Together with Chairil Anwar
 Apin was also part of the Gelanggang group of artists and writers. The group played an important role in the discourse of Indonesia’s cultural identity during the post-colonial period as outlined in the Gelanggang Manifesto of 1946.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a Chairil Anwar, one of Southeast Asia's most important poets. The figure's head angles away from the audience, and he is depicted to be wearing a blue shirt and is himself set against a colourful background. Yellow has been used to indicate the colour of the figure's skin. The artist's signature and date of work is found on the bottom left corner
metadata.subject_terms_1: figurative art  forms of expression (artistic concept)  identity
metadata.subject_terms_2: Figurative painting Figurative art Figurative expressionism  Identity  Anwar, Chairil, 1922-1949
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Executed after the Japanese Occupation, the work is a portrait of one of the most important poets in Southeast Asia. Here we can still observe Apin’s impressionist tendencies, similar to the works done during his  PERSAGI days. Together with Chairil Anwar, Apin was also part of the Gelanggang group of artists and writers. The group played an important role in the discourse of Indonesia’s cultural identity during the post-colonial period as outlined in the Gelanggang Manifesto of 1946.
